name: Trailing Spikemoss
description: Selaginella kraussiana, commonly known as African Clubmoss, Krauss's Spikemoss, or Trailing Spikemoss, is a primitive vascular plant native to Africa (particularly South Africa and tropical regions) and naturalized in New Zealand, the Azores, and parts of Europe. Despite its common names suggesting it's a moss or fern, it belongs to the Selaginellaceae family and is a lycophyte - an ancient group of vascular plants that predates both ferns and seed plants. It features small, scale-like leaves arranged in a flattened, branching pattern that creates a fern-like or moss-like appearance. The plant displays a creeping to semi-upright growth habit, forming dense mats or clumps. These are not true ferns but primitive vascular plants called "spike mosses" that can survive near-complete desiccation and revive when rehydrated - a process called poikilohydry shared with true mosses and some ferns. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds ancient, prehistoric texture with its primitive fern-like appearance. The plant produces spores in cone-like structures (strobili) at the tips of branches, rather than flowers or seeds.
careTips: Requires constant high humidity (70-90%) - ideal for closed terrariums or high-humidity environments
Can be sensitive to water quality - use distilled, rainwater, or filtered water to avoid mineral buildup
Propagates by division or stem cuttings - roots readily at nodes
Leaves curl when dry - this is a survival mechanism, rehydrate immediately
Native to Africa and naturalized in New Zealand - prefers warm, humid conditions (18-24Â°C)
Prefers bright indirect light to low light - avoid direct sunlight which can scorch leaves
Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged - allow slight drying between waterings
Well-draining substrate recommended - peat-based mix with perlite or sphagnum moss
Can be grown as ground cover in terrariums or in hanging baskets
Watch for spider mites and mealybugs in low humidity conditions
If leaves turn brown, increase humidity and check watering schedule
Can be grown outdoors in USDA zones 9-11 in shaded, humid locations
Fertilize monthly during growing season with diluted balanced fertilizer (quarter strength)
